title: Prescribed Offerings
shortSummary: Numbers 28 details the specific offerings and sacrifices commanded by God to Moses for the children of Israel, including daily, Sabbath, monthly, and festival sacrifices. This chapter emphasizes the importance of obedience in worship and maintaining a continual relationship with God through prescribed sacrifices.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Wilderness Period after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who receives God's instructions regarding the offerings and communicates them to the people.

keyCharacters.name: Children of Israel
keyCharacters.description: The nation of Israel commanded to observe the offerings and sacrifices as part of their covenant relationship with God.

definitions.definition: A sacrifice wholly consumed by fire on the altar, symbolizing complete surrender and atonement to God.
A grain offering made of flour mixed with oil, presented alongside animal sacrifices as an act of worship and dedication.
A libation of wine poured out as part of the sacrificial ritual, symbolizing the offering of one's life and joy to God.
A sacrifice made to atone for unintentional sins, restoring the relationship between God and His people.
A sacred assembly or gathering for worship, during which no servile work is to be done.

outline.heading: Daily Burnt Offerings
outline.description: God commands Moses to instruct Israel to offer two lambs daily, one in the morning and one at evening, with accompanying grain and drink offerings, establishing a continual burnt offering for a sweet savor to the LORD.

outline.heading: Sabbath Offerings
outline.description: Additional sacrifices are prescribed for every Sabbath, including two lambs and grain offerings, to be offered alongside the continual daily burnt offerings, highlighting the sanctity of the Sabbath.

outline.heading: Monthly Offerings
outline.description: At the beginning of each month, a special burnt offering involving bullocks, rams, lambs, and a sin offering goat is commanded, emphasizing regular renewal and atonement.

outline.heading: Passover and Feast of Unleavened Bread
outline.description: Detailed instructions for sacrifices during the Passover and the seven-day Feast of Unleavened Bread are given, including multiple animals and grain offerings, along with sin offerings, underscoring the importance of God's redemptive acts and holy convocations.

application: Commit to regular, consistent worship and devotion to God, reflecting the continual offerings prescribed in this chapter.
Recognize the importance of obedience in following God's commands, especially in matters of worship and holiness.
Approach God with reverence and dedication, offering your life as a 'living sacrifice' in response to His grace.
Honor God's appointed times for rest and worship, such as the Sabbath and holy convocations, as acts of faithfulness.

keyVerses.text: It is a continual burnt offering, which was ordained in mount Sinai for a sweet savour, a sacrifice made by fire unto the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the perpetual nature of worship and sacrifice God requires from His people.

keyVerses.text: And on the sabbath day two lambs of the first year without spot, and two tenth deals of flour for a meat offering, mingled with oil, and the drink offering thereof:
keyVerses.significance: It underscores the special offerings required on the Sabbath, emphasizing its holiness and distinctiveness.

keyVerses.text: And in the fourteenth day of the first month is the passover of the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the beginning of the Passover, a foundational feast pointing to God's redemption.

keyVerses.text: Ye shall offer them beside the continual burnt offering, and his meat offering, (they shall be unto you without blemish) and their drink offerings.
keyVerses.significance: It stresses the necessity of offering sacrifices without blemish, symbolizing purity and holiness required by God.
